comment: The Anti-Marshall. Although Leko has never played the Marshall (8 c3 d5), he has had plenty of experience of the White side of Frank's gambit, so would be well aware of all the nuances in it, so Kasparov avoids it. It's not that he is frightened of the Marshall. It's just that, if Black doesn't go in for anything speculative, he has a safe draw. Playing the Anti-Marshall against Nigel Short in their 1993 PCA title match was the advice given to Kasparov by the former Soviet giant and opening expert, Efim Geller.
reasoning: The comment does not explain the mistake made by the player, as it provides historical context and advice from a reputable source but does not directly address the specific move or its consequences.
moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7 6. Re1 b5 7. Bb3 O-O 8. a4
context: This is a game between Kasparov, G. (as White) and Leko, P. (as Black). Last move played: White plays Pawn to a4
